1007581867812491264.text:
Tcpdump from remote server to local mirrored port. 
shell$ ssh user@remote "/usr/sbin/tcpdump -i eth0 -w /dev/stdout -U 2>/dev/null" | tcprewrite --mtu-trunc --infile=- --outfile=/dev/stdout 2>/dev/null | tail -c +0 -f 2>/dev/null | tcpreplay --intf1=eth1 --topspeed - 2>/dev/null

1005775112027693056.text:
Sunday horror code:

md5('240610708') == md5('QNKCDZO')

The two strings have different hashes. PHP just converts the strings, which both start with "0e" to floating point numbers of value 0.0; and these are equal.
#PHP #LongestRunningJokeInWebHistory

998951579708424192.text: This seems like a very complex and error prone solution to a very rare problem. Or perhaps I'm missing a major relevant use case?https://twitter.com/mathias/status/998725981094506496 …

996728871256027138.text: the shape of a gadget. A smaller block size means that an attacker can more easily find a block of predictable plaintext. 3DES have 64 bit blocks which gives only 8 bytes to form the gadget, but still just enough to exploit: [

996728869909598208.text: Got a question regarding #efail crypto gadgets: "Are algorithms with smaller block sizes (3DES or Blowfish) safe from this attack?" - No, the problem of malleability lies in the use of CFB mode, regardless of the underlying crypto primitive. The block size puts constraints on 1/2

996665797249466373.text: My take on #efail: The responsibility for handling the issue is threefold, foremost the OpenPGP specification, the OpenPGP implementations of the specification, and the email clients interacting with the implementations. 1/

996665810625187840.text: This is not the last issue we will see with the current OpenPGP specification. Hopefully this, and coming issues, will speed up development. 9/9

996665808674836480.text: The current OpenPGP specification is complex and is provably hard to implement correctly. It is in desperate need of modernization, restriction and clarification. Work on updating the specification started in 2015, but has been painfully slow. 8/

996665807055835136.text: Leaving it up to an email client to make an informed security decision based on flawed output is not reasonable. That said, external resources should not be downloaded by default in a modern email client, since that in itself is a privacy intrusion. 7/

996665805508153344.text: How implementations of OpenPGP handles non-IP messages varies a lot. Some return errors, some returns the decrypted message along with a warning, and some treat non-IP the same as IP. This leaves it up to the invoking application to make the final security decisions. 6/

996665803964547072.text: OpenPGP introduced integrity protected (IP) messages through modification detection codes (MDCs) in 2000. Non-IP messages were left as part of the specification, even when it was updated in 2007, for legacy purposes and slow rate of adoption of MDC. 5/

996665802244882432.text: There are two elements to this attack, modification of encrypted messages and loading of external resources in emails. Having experience with analysing the specification and having audited a number of implementations, I will focus on the OpenPGP aspect of the attack. 4/

996665800542097408.text: For the attack to succeed, the attacker must obtain a copy of an email encrypted for the victim, modify it, send it to the victim, the victim's email client must decrypt the message, ignore any decryption errors and load external resources. 3/

996665798885339136.text: The attack in a tweet: an encrypted message is injected with an unclosed html tag pointing to the attacker's domain, upon decryption the tag is rendered which also includes the decrypted message as part of the URL. 2/

63324637932691456.text: @Dinosn you're right and in chrome the DoS only affect the same tab, since each tab runs in its own process. Limited DoS perhaps is better?

63279448165851136.text: The alleged "0day BoF/DoS" in Chrome (http://1337day.com/exploits/15920) is neither. Just exhausts memory by building a long string.

63255951880359938.text: @Dinosn @thanpolas @xanda No, it's not a BoF. Not even DoS, because it only affects that tab. It just exhausts the memory. Not exploitable!

28706941830.text: @0x6D6172696F FXSHRXW is the biggest word you can write. You can also use type=i for roman numerals for values up to 4000. MCCCXXXVII

28705756551.text: @0x6D6172696F 9999999999 = 2*2^32 + 1410065407. OL uses signed 32 bit integer for the value. Biggest value is 2147483647 = 2^31-1
